Report: Robert Sturdy (A7-0365/2011)

 
  
 		 

  Luís Paulo Alves (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I am voting for this report, as it clearly analyses the barriers and tariff policies that currently exist in trade involving EU Member States. In addition, I believe that it is important to seek to remove the existing barriers to European entrepreneurs who have difficulties in exporting to EU trading partners which impose serious barriers to European imports. It is necessary to respect the fact that the creation of tariffs also depends partly on national and regional choices, such as at the level of genetically modified organisms, but in general, we can send a message that closer cooperation between the world’s major trading partners will allow the economies of all the stakeholders to be revived. Finally, it is important to pay particular attention to the needs of developing countries.

 
  
 		 

  Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this resolution on trade and investment barriers. Open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at global level. The Commission must act proactively to remove or at the very least reduce the restrictive impact of non-tariff barriers (NTBs) on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets. I agree with the rapporteur that this must be a top priority of the new EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. The Commission should raise the issue of NTBs with all of the EU’s trading partners, above all, with the strategic partners with whom the EU does most of its trade. The EU should also carefully review its own trade measures in order to remove any illegitimate hindrances to open and free trade, and become a true frontrunner in the fight against NTBs.

 
  
 		 

  Elena Oana Antonescu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) Removing trade barriers is one of the most important actions which the EU authorities can take to be able to stimulate the competitiveness of the European Union’s economic operators. Providing European economic operators with free access to market outlets is intended to stimulate their competitiveness and innovative capability, as this is one of the European Union’s economic policy priorities.

The European Union has the duty, along with its trade partners and the European External Action Service, to define and renegotiate the technical and quality standards to prevent them from becoming non-tariff barriers blocking EU producers’ access to external markets. Negotiating transitional periods and consensual trade methods with the EU’s partners will help give a boost to European producers, in addition to protecting European production standards or geographical indications. The EU must also insist on ensuring the principle of reciprocity. Just as companies outside the EU can participate in public procurement procedures in the EU, European companies must also have free access to calls for tender from the authorities in foreign countries.

I voted in favour of this report.

 
  
 		 

  Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report. EU companies with activities in third countries continue to face major barriers. Non-tariff barriers (NTBs) remain one of the greatest problems and refer to all trade restricting measures other than import duties (tariffs) that limit imports. NTBs include direct price influencers (such as export subsidies or drawbacks, countervailing and anti-dumping duties, exchange rate manipulations, methods of import valuation, customs surcharges, unreasonable standards and inspection procedures), and indirect price influencers (such as import licensing, import quotas and ‘voluntary’ export restraints). Removing or reducing unjustified NTBs and other regulatory obstacles applied by the EU’s key strategic partner countries by means of regulatory dialogue should be one of the key regulatory priorities of the new EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. The issue of access to public procurement for EU companies in third countries also needs to be addressed. Public procurement procedures in the EU’s strategic partner countries tend to be closed to foreign participants and are still relatively unaffected by international commitments, while the EU is much more open than other countries in this regard. Under EU law, European and foreign companies can tender for European public contracts without discrimination, and the EU must therefore become more involved and reach agreements with its main trading partners to give European companies fair and equitable access to procurement procedures in third countries.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Berlato (PPE), in writing. – (IT) By Non-tariff barriers, which were first discussed as part of WTO multilateral trade negotiations in 1979, we mean all trade restricting measures which limit imports. I believe that open and, above all, fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for EU businesses competing at the global level. The bilateral and plurilateral negotiations are also a good opportunity for the Commission to step up regulatory cooperation with the EU’s main trading partners. In my opinion, the Commission should act proactively to reduce the restrictive impact of non-tariff barriers on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets. This shall be a priority of the new EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. Furthermore, with respect to free trade agreements (FTAs) between the EU and third countries, it is vital to make sure that these provide sufficient reciprocity in market access and mutual benefits to both parties. The ultimate aim should be to limit disputes and the associated costs of those for European businesses, without prejudice to the quality of the resulting regulatory environment.

 
  
 		 

  Mara Bizzotto (EFD), in writing. – (IT) In my opinion, Europe is not doing enough to protect its industry and the service sector from its foreign competitors, which, in the meantime, are protecting themselves with internal protection measures which are much more robust and effective than our own.

In any case, during trade negotiations with the largest partners and in EU production legislation, we should try to take into account Europe’s need to balance trading conditions and the quality and quantity of non-tariff barriers between us and our trading partners.

I also think the issue of non-tariff barriers should be a part of all free trade agreements. We should look into the possibility of establishing an early warning mechanism to detect new unjustified barriers, and we should look again at the sensitive subject of the supply of raw materials. That is why I voted in favour of the Sturdy report.

 
  
 		 

  Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this report because it aims to draw attention to trade and investment barriers preventing European Union companies from accessing markets in third countries. This report draws particular attention to so-called non-tariff barriers (NTBs), which are direct or indirect price influencers. Such barriers include export subsidies or drawbacks, exchange rate manipulations, lengthy customs procedures, unreasonable standards and inspection procedures, as well as import licensing, import quotas or export restraints. In its report, the European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission, which is responsible for international negotiations on behalf of the EU, to fight more actively against NTBs in world trade fora. Parliament also calls on the Commission to pay more attention to ensuring that free trade agreements concluded between the EU and third countries adhere to the principle of reciprocity where market access is concerned. In other words, they should ensure mutual benefits for both contracting parties.

 
  
 		 

  Vito Bonsignore (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The report presented was high quality and I voted in favour of it, since it deals with a subject that is very sensitive, that of non-tariff barriers, in the climate of financial crisis that Europe is currently experiencing.

Companies, European exporters, analysts and the Commission have identified non-tariff barriers as a growing hindrance to free access to partner countries’ markets; other than duties, these are trade restricting measures that limit imports. There are two main types: direct price influencers such as export subsidies or drawbacks, and indirect price influencers such as import licensing.

These are measures therefore of a potentially legitimate nature, but are often misused. The Commission must act proactively to reduce the impact of these barriers on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets.

In this context, the European Union should address the issue with a holistic strategy, reviewing trade measures, in order to remove illegitimate barriers and pay particular attention to current and future free trade agreements, making sure that there is sufficient reciprocity in market access and also making provision for bilateral safeguard mechanisms which include appropriate corrective measures.

 
  
 		 

  Philippe Boulland (PPE), in writing. – (FR) If we are to help our companies gain market share abroad, we must not only demand the removal of barriers restricting trade between the European Union and its trading partners, but also secure reciprocity of market access. To this end, we must keep an up-to-date inventory of these barriers and put in place an early warning system. In view of the rapid growth in global trade outside the European Union, the Commission must urgently draw up a legislative proposal on an instrument for reciprocity in respect of access to third-country government procurement markets. The impact of foreign direct investment on the internal market also needs to be evaluated so as to forestall any potential adverse effects on European innovation and know-how in certain strategic sectors. Our European companies are internationally recognised for their know-how in the fields of infrastructure, transport, construction and advanced technology. Therefore, it is up to us to do all we can to enable them to access new markets.

 
  
 		 

  Lara Comi (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted in favour of this report because I think globalisation only has positive effects when we can control the direction it takes. My generation on this continent has access to a range of goods and services that would be unimaginable in other periods of history and in other parts of the world. At the same time, the opening of international trade has allowed the economy to grow from strength to strength, with positive effects for the majority of citizens. This does not mean that we should not consider balancing measures, which, despite themselves, make us more exposed on the international market, and on the subject of equality, we cannot allow barriers which protect inefficiencies that are of exclusive advantage to the few people who benefit from them. I wait to see the Commission’s proposal on this issue for further increasing the wellbeing of European citizens.

 
  
 		 

  George Sabin Cutaş (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for this resolution because the World Trade Organisation is the most suitable forum for regulating free and fair trade globally. On the other hand, we need to reform the way the WTO operates and its decision-making process to eliminate the lack of democracy.

I find it regrettable that several developing countries largely open to trade had to suffer due to the economic crisis, especially in the form of job losses. I think that the European Union must play a strong role in the negotiations for concluding the Doha Development Agenda by promoting the interests of the least developed or developing countries. We must think of the needs of weak states and create fairer rules for them through the auspices of the WTO.

 
  
 		 

  Vasilica Viorica Dăncilă (S&D), in writing. – (RO) Trade relations with countries from all over the world have always provided and continue to provide a basis for developing economic relations with these states at every level. As these relations are very often hampered by various barriers, I think that the proposal for the European Commission to examine the possibility of introducing an early warning mechanism to detect such barriers is useful.

While in the midst of developing the European External Action Service’s activities, I believe that the EU must consider getting more involved in EU missions precisely so as to be able to identify such barriers in good time and find solutions for avoiding stalemate in trade relations with third countries and, in particular, any stalemate hampering investors.

 
  
 		 

  Mário David (PPE), in writing. – (PT) In addition to its comprehensive, properly contextualised analysis, this own-initiative report by my fellow Member of the Committee on International Trade, Mr Sturdy, proposes various concrete measures aimed at promoting free trade on a global scale, in line with the rules set out by the World Trade Organisation. In the 15 pages of his report, which I recommend that all those who are interested in matters relating to international trade read, especially in relation to its legislative framework in recent years, I would also emphasise the need to eliminate non-tariff barriers to trade and investment, as one of the main objectives of EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. Of the many corrective and preventative measures that it proposes, I would like to highlight only one: that the Commission should study an early warning system to detect non-tariff barriers, and the strengthening of its existing analytical tools for the better qualitative evaluation of these barriers. From what I have said thus far, it is easy to see that I have voted for the report, and I would like to congratulate Mr Sturdy for the excellent work that he has carried out.

 
  
 		 

  Anne Delvaux (PPE), in writing. – (FR) I believe that the removal or, at the very least, the reduction of non-tariff barriers and other regulatory barriers should be a priority in the regulations concerning the Union’s new trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. Hence, I believe it is vital to call on the Commission to systematically address non-tariff barriers as part of a holistic strategy, including enhanced regulatory dialogue, with respect to all the EU’s trading partners. Furthermore, it is important to improve regulatory cooperation and convergence of regulatory requirements on the basis of international standards and, where possible, engage in regulatory dialogue to address existing or potential future barriers to trade with a view to limiting disputes and their associated significant trade costs.

 
  
 		 

  Edite Estrela (S&D), in writing. – (PT) I voted for the report as I believe that it is going in the right direction by promoting the combating of unfair competition, the elimination of unjustified non-tariff barriers, the strengthening of respect for intellectual property rights, protection for EU consumers and, in particular, the protection of the environment inside and outside the EU.

 
  
 		 

  Diogo Feio (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The freedom of trade and rejection of protectionism are defining elements of the European project, such as it is. The EU is based on freedom of movement within its borders, but also on freedom of trade and investment with third countries. This is the correct model, and I am not asking for it to be reviewed.

However, as the French President rightly pointed out only last week in Marseille, we cannot impose quality standards on our producers and industries if these are not then met by the products that we import. In the same way, we cannot be a more open space, yet fail to see our openness to imports and foreign investment reciprocated with acceptance by other important markets that Europeans want to enter. Finally, free trade agreements, which are important and opportune, need to be reciprocal, as otherwise we will be condemning the European economy to a slow death.

 
  
 		 

  José Manuel Fernandes (PPE), in writing. – (PT) This report concerns the barriers to trade and investment in the European Union, which hinder competitiveness, economic growth and thus wealth creation and employment. As the rapporteur, Mr Sturdy, says, ‘open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at global level’. The issue of barriers to trade and investment has been subject to a multilevel approach: the Transatlantic Economic Council has decided to strengthen cooperation between the US and the EU, in accordance with the Trade Principles for Information and Communication Technology Services. Progress has also been noted in the automotive sector, and a high-level conference is expected to take place. All this shows that the elimination of barriers to trade is a priority for the EU. Although I agree with the opening up recommended in the report, and therefore voted for it, I also believe that a mechanism should be created under the World Trade Organisation to speed up the elimination of non-tariff barriers in a peaceful yet efficient way, or by regulatory measures on trade that limit imports.

 
  
 		 

  João Ferreira (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) The rapporteur gives the impression of being a staunch defender of free trade, and it is this vision that prevails in the report. This vision is in line with the dominant positions in Parliament, uniting the right with the social democrats. We consider the content of this report to be unacceptable.

We are looking at yet another defence of the unbridled liberalisation and deregulation of international trade. Despite the recognition that among the so-called barriers to trade, there are practices, regulations and procedures that are justified on the basic grounds of public interest, they are seeking to restrict these barriers as much as possible, upholding a restrictive view of the public interest. They want to force various countries to lift their non-tariff barriers in the name of the free movement of products from the EU, to combat favouritism towards national companies.

The liberalisation of world trade has disastrous consequences for many sectors of economic activity. It causes the destruction of productive activity and jobs, affects the capacity to create and distribute wealth, increases the dependence on foreign markets and results in chronic and growing imbalances in trade; in short, economic and social breakdown. Defending the right of each country to produce in a sustainable way is vital for the future. This should be done in the name of a new economic, social, energy-oriented and environmental rationale, something that the neoliberal model not only fails to deliver but even renders impossible.

 
  
 		 

  Ilda Figueiredo (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (PT) This report is essentially focused on the defence of free trade, which is in line with the dominant positions in Parliament, uniting the right and the social democrats. However, we reject it. We are looking at yet another defence of the unbridled liberalisation and deregulation of international trade, which does not take account of the different levels of development in different countries, nor the right of each country to produce in a sustainable way. Despite the recognition that among the so-called barriers to trade there are practices, regulations and procedures that are justified on the basic grounds of public interest, they are seeking to restrict these barriers as much as possible, upholding a restrictive view of the public interest. Although they recognise that among the so-called barriers to trade, there are practices, regulations and procedures that are justified on the basic grounds of public interest, they are seeking to restrict these barriers as much as possible, upholding a restrictive view of the public interest. They want to force various countries to lift their non-tariff barriers in the name of the free movement of products from the EU, to combat favouritism towards national companies.

The liberalisation of world trade has disastrous consequences for many sectors of economic activity. As we know, this causes the destruction of productive capacity and jobs, affects the capacity to create and distribute wealth, increases the dependence on foreign markets and results in chronic and growing imbalances in trade. In short, it leads to economic and social breakdown.

 
  
 		 

  Monika Flašíková Benová (S&D), in writing. – (SK) The rule-based multilateral trading system, which was established under the aegis of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), is the most suitable framework for regulating and promoting open and fair trade and guaranteeing the development of fair and equitable global trade rules. Efforts are still needed to reform the WTO with a view to making it more democratic and efficient and clarifying its relations with other key international organisations. The EU should continue to give priority to achieving a balanced outcome from the Doha Development Agenda (DDA), which would support the integration of developing countries, particularly the least developed countries, into the international trading system and contribute to establishing and enforcing fairer and more equitable multilateral trade rules among all its members. EU exporters often face many types of restriction in foreign markets. The EU should therefore actively defend its industries, whenever necessary, against violations of agreed rules and WTO standards and principles by its trading partners, using all available means, including multilateral and bilateral dispute resolution mechanisms and WTO-compatible trade defence instruments. All barriers resulting from the inconsistent implementation of bilateral, plurilateral and multilateral trade rules are unjustified, and regulatory dialogue should, in particular, respect the right of all states to enhance human rights, environmental rules, social rules and public health.

 
  
 		 

  Brice Hortefeux (PPE), in writing. – (FR) Freedom of movement is one of the founding principles of the European Economic Community, and in a world in which the drawbacks of economic interdependence have also been revealed, it is essential to lay the foundations for fairer trade, with respect shown for the principle of reciprocity. It is a fact: the European Union still comes up against unjustifiable tariff and regulatory barriers erected by some of its partners, which limits both our companies’ access to these high growth potential markets and investment. By 2015, 90% of global growth will be generated outside the European Union. This is a parameter we cannot ignore. The future of our companies will also be at stake outside our borders. That is why I support the measures proposed in this report to lift these unjustifiable restrictions: a Commission-compiled inventory of key barriers, the establishment of an early warning mechanism, and a strengthening of public procurement disciplines which could lead to the presentation of an instrument for reciprocity in respect of access to third-country government procurement markets by next year.

 
  
 		 

  Juozas Imbrasas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour because the EU should actively defend its industries, whenever necessary, against violations of agreed rules and WTO standards and principles by its trading partners using all available means, including multilateral and bilateral dispute settlement mechanisms and WTO-compatible trade defence instruments. Removing or reducing unjustified non-tariff barriers (NTBs) and other regulatory obstacles applied by the EU’s key strategic partner countries by means of regulatory dialogue should be one of the key regulatory priorities of the new EU trade policy under the Europe 2020 strategy. I believe that any barriers resulting from the incoherent implementation of bilateral and multilateral trade rules are unjustified. Regulatory dialogue should respect the right of all states to strengthen human rights, environmental rules, social rules and public health. The Commission should draw a clear distinction between those NTBs which give rise to unfair distortions of competition and those which reflect legitimate public policy aims, notably in relation to public health and the protection of the environment. Insistence on reciprocity of market access for industrialised and emerging countries should be an integral part of EU trade strategy, on a par with the removal or lowering of NTBs.

 
  
 		 

  Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE), in writing. – (DE) The restrictive effects of non-tariff barriers on European companies must be eliminated or at least reduced. This must be one of the most important priorities of the new EU trade policy, which forms part of the Europe 2020 strategy. As far as the free trade agreements between the EU and third countries are concerned, it is essential that they have an adequate level of reciprocal market access. I would like to repeat my call for a sustainability chapter in trade agreements which must be linked to safeguard clauses. Quality requirements and standards, in particular in the agricultural industry, play an important role in the EU internal market. These standards should also be applied to third countries as part of trade agreements.

 
  
 		 

  Constance Le Grip (PPE) , in writing. – (FR) I voted in favour of Robert Sturdy’s report on trade and investment barriers. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on this subject, I am pleased that the European Parliament is establishing clear guidelines for the European Commission to follow in order to provide European companies with the means to compete on a level playing field with their foreign counterparts. This is particularly important because, by 2015, 90% of global growth will be generated outside the European Union. It is therefore necessary to clearly identify the barriers that hamper trade between the European Union and its trading partners, and to remove them in order to help our companies gain market share abroad. Reforming European trade policy according to the principles of reciprocity, equity and fair competition should be one of our priorities. I am also pleased to see that the European Parliament supports the idea of considering, at European level, an evaluation of the impact of foreign direct investment on the internal market so as to forestall any potential adverse effects on European innovation and know-how in certain strategic sectors. This was the aim of one of the amendments I tabled.

 
  
 		 

  Morten Løkkegaard (ALDE), in writing. – (DA) I am voting in favour of the report on trade and investment barriers because it indicates practical solutions for how we can achieve more free trade and points out the damaging effects of protectionism. As a liberal, I believe that free trade should be promoted and protectionism should be combated. In the first round, we must adopt free trade agreements with China and other important trading partners, which, in time, may become full WTO agreements. Unfortunately, things are heading in the wrong direction in these areas, as the report points out. Lastly, I would like to mention that I am not keen on the frequent references to reciprocity, as to my mind, this is another word for protectionism. Overall, however, the report is heading in the right direction. In the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, I am working on getting as many references to reciprocity and protectionism removed or reduced as much as possible in the European Parliament’s reports, and this has also been successful this time. The result is therefore palatable.

 
  
 		 

  David Martin (S&D), in writing. – I voted for this report, which calls on the Commission to pay particular attention to tackling unjustified NTBs – which are a barrier to trade – while recognising the importance of legitimate public policy aims in relation to human rights, environmental rules and social standards, for example in GMO laws.

 
  
 		 

  Mario Mauro (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Non-tariff barriers (NTBs) should be given at least as much attention as is currently afforded tariff elimination in all appropriate regulatory fora.   Nuno Melo (PPE), in writing. – (PT) Given that the issue of non-tariff barriers, which are a growing hindrance to free access to partner countries’ markets, include a series of trade restricting measures other than import duties, which limit imports, it is important that the Commission acts in a proactive way to eliminate or at least reduce the restrictive impact of such non-tariff barriers, so that the export capacity of European countries is not affected, and thus ensure and maintain equitable competitive conditions for European companies that are competing in the global market.

 
  
 		 

  Rareş-Lucian Niculescu (PPE), in writing. – (RO) I voted for this report because, apart from lifting the trade barriers hindering trade between the EU and its trade partners, we must also establish reciprocity in terms of market access. This will enable us to increase European companies’ chances of winning larger shares of the foreign market. This is an important consideration, given that by 2015, 90% of global economic growth will be generated outside the European Union, and we must help European investors capitalise on all the existing opportunities.

 
  
 		 

  Rolandas Paksas (EFD), in writing. – (LT) I voted in favour of this resolution. I believe that, given the current economic situation, particular attention must be paid to trade and investment barriers faced by the European services sector. It should be noted that non-tariff measures and various crisis measures are particularly important given the higher added value of the services sector and the EU’s position as the largest exporter of services. It is very important for the EU to actively defend its industries and demand that the EU’s key strategic partner countries remove unjustified NTBs and other regulatory obstacles, or at least reduce their scope.

 
  
 		 

  Alfredo Pallone (PPE), in writing. – (IT) The liberalisation of trade and investments can bring only advantages and thus, I voted in favour of the report. The benefits of an open market are clearly greater and best felt in those countries which have eliminated customs duties and non-tariff barriers, restrictions that prevent European businesses trading freely with foreign markets, which would undoubtedly represent a considerable benefit, increasing demand for goods and common wealth. At a time like this, the global economy needs to support itself and cooperate in order to bring about recovery as soon as possible.

 
  
 		 

  Georgios Papanikolaou (PPE), in writing. – (EL) I voted in favour of the own-initiative report. Non-tariff barriers, which appear in various forms (anti-dumping duties, exchange rate manipulations, methods of import valuation, customs surcharges and so forth), are technical, complicated and sensitive from a political and social point of view, because certain measures are applied by governments in the general interest. However, some NTBs exert a restrictive effect on the ability of European undertakings to penetrate foreign markets. The EU’s new trade policy within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy should therefore be more outward-looking, so that, where feasible, the Commission can enter into agreement with the EU’s main trading partners in order to eliminate any restrictive and protectionist arrangements that cause commercial distortions.

 
  
 		 

  Maria do Céu Patrão Neves (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The most sensible way of finding the right balance between trading partners is the existence of an open market, albeit one which is offset with particular exceptions, which protects certain sensitive sectors of the economy for each partner, in order to enable it to adjust gradually and prepare itself for global competition before actually opening itself up to it. I voted for this report because I believe that this legislation supports this objective.

 
  
 		 

  Aldo Patriciello (PPE), in writing. – (IT) Considering that open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at the global level, non-tariff barriers (NTBs) represent a form of trade restriction on imports. Hence, the Commission should act proactively to remove or at the very least reduce the restrictive impact of NTBs on the capacity of European businesses to access foreign markets. I agree with all the amendments tabled on the report, and I voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Paulo Rangel (PPE), in writing. – (PT) The European Union, when seen from a dual perspective, is committed to a project for economic order based on the liberalisation of trade. Firstly, it deals with the purpose of the internal market, and secondly, it covers something about the regulation put forward by the World Trade Organisation, with which the EU is associated. Whatever the basic position that it adopts in this regard, it is certain that, within loose limits, a system of free intermediation in trade translates into what has been called a win-win situation; both the countries, or group of countries, which give up a more protectionist approach will end up making more profit together than individually. In view of this, the reduction of non-tariff barriers is justified, through subtle ways of introducing limitations on international trade, such as export subsidies, anti-dumping duties and exchange rate manipulations. These are barriers that do not follow the ‘formal’ method of introducing a tariff duty. In view of what has been said, a policy action aimed at the gradual abolition of these instruments is justified, while full commitment should be maintained to a system of exceptions, especially for weaker sectors of the economy. I therefore voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Crescenzio Rivellini (PPE), in writing. – (IT) During the part-session in Strasbourg today, we voted on the report by Mr Sturdy on reducing and removing trade barriers and unjustified regulatory obstacles applied by the EU’s strategic partners to trade and investment.

It was considered that the European Union, which has sole competence over trade and investment, should address non-tariff barriers (NTBs) as part of the Europe 2020 strategy, bringing together both a diplomatic effort to be pursued in close cooperation with the European External Action Service (EEAS), and an enhanced regulatory dialogue with the EU’s trade partners, in order to put NTBs at the heart of international negotiations.

It was also hoped that the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and the Commission would work together to underline the advantages of trade liberalisation so that the European Union can fully enjoy the opportunities of an open market, while at the same time offsetting possible negative externalities of widespread liberalisation by mutually agreeing with their trade partners on certain transitional exceptions.

 
  
 		 

  Raül Romeva i Rueda (Verts/ALE), in writing. – Abstention. The rapporteur has acknowledged that his main position was to fight protectionism in all its forms. He believes that open and fair trade is the best way to ensure and maintain a level playing field for European businesses competing at the global level. He maintains that he has always been a strong supporter of the multilateral trading system, and defends the rules established within the WTO framework as the best means to ensure equitable treatment for all global trading partners. We Greens agree on some important points of the proposal. However, we would have preferred to vote down some of the recitals (G, L, M, N and O). We tried and we failed. So, in the end, we have abstained.

 
  
 		 

  Oreste Rossi (EFD), in writing. – (IT) I am in favour of the report’s text which defines non-tariff barriers as all trade restricting measures other than import duties that limit imports. These measures may influence the price of goods directly, for example, export subsidies or drawbacks, or indirectly, for example, through import licensing and import quotas.

The issue of non-tariff trade barriers is recognised in the report’s text as being technically and politically sensitive because some of these measures are being implemented by governments in the public interest. I think we need to find the right balance between trade openness and temporary market closures using the institution of transitional exceptions through mutual agreements with trade partners.

 
  
 		 

  Tokia Saïfi (PPE), in writing. – (FR) For the first time this year, the European Commission has taken an inventory of the trade and investment barriers faced by our companies in third-country markets. This initiative, which I welcome, will better enable us to combat these barriers and therefore help to open up new markets. The European Parliament’s report, which concerns this inventory, proposes additional solutions, two of which seem particularly interesting to me. Firstly, keeping an up-to-date inventory of these barriers, which companies could consult to better prepare themselves before entering a market. Secondly, putting in place an early warning mechanism based on the expertise and local knowledge of the EU delegations and foreign embassies and consulates. These two solutions can be implemented quickly without generating new costs. That is why I supported them in the vote.

 
  
 		 

  Matteo Salvini (EFD), in writing, – (IT) I voted for this report. The rapporteur, Mr Sturdy, and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) have done excellent work. In any case, it is right to emphasise that certain states may raise barriers to legitimately protect their own economy and their own consumers. Of course, the text is lacking one important consideration which is that at some point, even the European Union might need to start protecting its own fabric of production rather than limiting itself to only requesting reductions in duties and the removal of non-tariff barriers. In my opinion, a real trade policy should not limit itself to this alone and should consider the interests of European small and medium-sized enterprises first and foremost.

 
  
 		 

  Sergio Paolo Francesco Silvestris (PPE), in writing. – (IT) European producers often find it difficult to penetrate and trade competitively in Eastern markets, particularly in the automotive, aviation and aeronautics sectors.   Silvia-Adriana Ţicău (S&D), in writing. – (RO) I voted for the European Parliament resolution on trade and investment barriers because I think that removing or reducing unjustified non-tariff barriers (NTBs) and other regulatory obstacles applied by the EU’s key strategic partner countries by means of regulatory dialogue should be one of the priorities of the EU’s new trade policy. We call on the Commission to address these issues in all multilateral and bilateral trade agreements, especially in Free Trade Agreements, and to ensure that NTBs are given at least as much attention as is currently afforded tariff elimination in all the appropriate regulatory forums, particularly during its negotiations with industrialised and emerging economies.

I think that due priority should be given to trade and investment barriers that affect European service sectors, including IT and telecommunications, financial services, construction, retail and distribution. We call on the Commission to pursue, with regard to raw materials, a sustainable, comprehensive and cross-sector strategy so that the export restrictions and taxes applied by some countries to raw materials do not affect global economic development and the fulfilment of the Europe 2020 strategy objectives.

 
  
 		 

  Derek Vaughan (S&D), in writing. – European businesses competing at a global level should not be hindered by non-tariff barriers (NTBs), which can hamper free access to partner countries’ markets. The Commission needs to act to reduce the negative impact of unjustified NTBs, which are a barrier to trade. The EU needs to examine its trade measures in order to make sure that trade is made as open and free as possible. Trade policy should be a priority for the EU 2020 strategy and I echo calls for the Commission to address problems with the existing WTO Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade.   Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL), in writing. – (FR) I voted against this report, which lauds ultraliberal dogma: ‘Let us remove all barriers to global trade (we are talking about non-tariff barriers here) and trade will bring prosperity to all those who make it their religion’. It goes without saying that in the middle of an economic crisis, where each day brings a new batch of unemployed people and social outcasts, this text is a provocation that ignores worsening social inequalities and environmental issues. I refuse to accept this headlong flight into free trade, without rules and without morals. Trade is not simply a question of business and profits. It must allow for the movement of people, ideas and goods, taking each country and each population into account, and work towards building new relationships.

 
  
 		 

  Angelika Werthmann (NI), in writing. – (DE) Over the years, various trade barriers have caused major problems for the international market. One particularly sensitive area involves non-tariff trade barriers, which are often put in place by governments in what is allegedly the public interest. However, to a certain extent, they are at risk of being abused (protectionism under the guise of legitimate political objectives). Suitable measures for identifying and removing or reducing non-tariff barriers include free trade agreements between the EU and third countries, periodic reassessment of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) agreement, a joint engagement by the Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) with the EU’s trade partners and the establishment of an early warning mechanism. I have voted in favour.

 
  
 		 

  Iva Zanicchi (PPE), in writing. – (IT) I voted for the text presented by Mr Sturdy which analyses the restrictive measures facing international trade which have been adopted in recent years by the European Union’s major partners.

Finding the right balance between trade openness and temporary market closures is essentially the equilibrium EU trade negotiators have to seek in the run-up to all trade negotiations, and especially free trade agreements.

IN THE CHAIR: ALEJO VIDAL-QUADRAS
Vice-President

 

9. Approval of the minutes of the previous sitting: see Minutes
Video of the speeches

10. Common security and defence policy (Article 36 TEU) - Impact of the financial crisis on the defence sector (debate)
Video of the speeches
 

  President. – The next item is the joint debate on

- the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the common security and defence policy (Article 36 TEU) (2010/2802(RSP)), and

- the report by Krzysztof Lisek, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the impact of the financial crisis on the defence sector in the EU Member States (2011/2177(INI)) (A7-0428/2011).

 
  
 

  Catherine Ashton, Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, can I begin by also thanking Mr Lisek for his report. As I said last night when I saw him, I come from the European Defence Agency where they, too, would wish me to express their thanks for the work that he has done.

There is no debate about the common security and defence policy (CSDP) this year that can ignore the financial crisis which has led to a wave of defence cuts across the European Union. This has resulted in both the increased focus on pooling and sharing of military capabilities and in the current staff shortfalls we are experiencing in important CSDP missions and operations.

But the demand for the EU to do more and better is getting stronger. We need to be able to respond to the complex threats of today – crises from cyber-threats, energy security and others – and we need to assume our global responsibilities whilst showing real value for money. To deliver value for money, we need CSDP action to be based on coherent and effective strategies and a truly comprehensive approach and equipped with the right capabilities, as was restated in the Foreign Affairs Council on 1 December.

The budgetary constraints force us to save, but they are also a driver of closer collaboration; whether on pooling and sharing of defence assets, joint programming of development aid, or solidarity in the evacuation of European nationals from scenes of conflict or disaster. The message is clear: doing better with less.

The 1 December Foreign Affairs Council endorsed my call to maximise synergies and strengthen cooperation – complementing instead of duplicating each other. I am committed to ensuring that the actions by the External Action Service, the Commission and the EU Member States reinforce rather than compete with each other.

At the meeting of 1 December, we also agreed that the EU needs to improve its operations by more clearly identifying needs and acting with clear objectives and clear exit strategies. The European Parliament, alongside national parliaments and governments, plays an important role in ensuring the democratic oversight of EU foreign, security and defence policy, as recognised in my declaration on political accountability.

I want to focus for a moment on some important achievements during the course of this year.

At the level of structures, we have established the External Action Service and it is now equipped to deal with crises better, faster and smarter. When the Service was launched in January 2011, the Arab Spring required our immediate response. In light of this experience, we have set up the Crisis Management Board and Crisis Platform, which also dealt effectively with crisis situations in Ivory Coast, Libya and the Horn of Africa. These structures are central to our capacity to respond, and maintain their direct reporting line to me while working closely with the rest of the service.

We have also improved the early warning capacity through the Situation Room and the Conflict Prevention Group and we are currently exploring how to strengthen the security policy expertise in EU delegations. All of this has been achieved using and restructuring the existing resources and improving their flexibility and efficiency rather than by seeking other expensive and complex solutions.

We are turning a comprehensive approach into comprehensive action and I believe the External Action Service is uniquely placed for this. We can join up all of the instruments of the European Union and cover conflict prevention, development and conflict resolution. We are putting this to full use in the Horn of Africa and in the Southern Neighbourhood.

Some people try and say that we are facing some sort of fatigue on CSDP, yet this year has been a year of intensive work on this area, with concrete results, and ending with comprehensive and, I believe, forward-looking Council conclusions.

On military capabilities, the 30 November European Defence Agency Steering Board delivered concrete Member States’ commitments in specific projects, including in areas where the Libya crisis showed our shortfalls. This is a good first step towards more substantial achievements next spring, also in view of the NATO Chicago summit which I will attend.

But as indicated by the honourable Member Mr Lisek’s report, there is no alternative to cooperation in this area. Multinational cooperation must become the rule rather than the exception in order to preserve and develop Europe’s defence capabilities. I agree with what Mr Lisek says: pooling and sharing is a means of delivering enhanced capabilities and of offsetting defence budgets cuts.

As the Head of the European Defence Agency, I will continue to make every effort to facilitate cooperation among and between Member States and to increase the global competitiveness and efficiency of the European defence industry.

In July, I presented a comprehensive report on CSDP. It set out the parameters for further work, both in terms of hardware – our military and civilian capabilities – and software – how we plan and conduct operations and engage with our partners. The Foreign Affairs Council on 1 December welcomed my work to strengthen the CSDP.

Member States’ initiatives, such as the Weimar initiative and subsequent contributions, have provided an added impetus to work. I am pleased, too, that we found a pragmatic way forward on the issue of the planning and conduct of CSDP operations. We are now beginning planning for the activation of the operations centre for the Horn of Africa operations by the next Foreign Affairs Council in January. This will allow us to test this tool, with a view to strengthening civilian-military synergies and again to draw lessons for the future.

I believe that we have achieved a lot of progress in working with our partners. In the area of security and defence, the relationship with NATO is essential. It is recognised in the Lisbon Treaty, which is the first of the EU Treaties to explicitly refer to NATO. The breadth of EU instruments can be usefully combined with the depth of NATO’s role on defence. The two organisations can and should reinforce each other’s work.

I have worked hard to establish a good, close working relationship with NATO Secretary-General Rasmussen, to bring the EU and NATO closer through a pragmatic step-by-step approach, while maintaining the overall objective of a true organisation-to-organisation relationship.

The Libya crisis again showed a clear need for this. We work hand in hand in many theatres, and we owe it to our people in the field. I am also pleased to confirm that on capabilities in particular – whether labelled pooling and sharing or smart defence – we have now achieved an unprecedented level of cooperation.

The UN remains, of course, a longstanding partner, and we are turning this partnership into reality: in theatres where both are or could be engaged, in Afghanistan, Somalia, Kosovo and Libya, and through our strategic dialogue. I have also personally engaged on security and defence with our strategic partners, not least regarding areas like the Horn of Africa or in Libya. I signed a framework agreement with the United States of America in June on their participation in CSDP civilian missions and already 60 US citizens under EU chain of command are operating in Kosovo and Afghanistan.

I also want to foster closer cooperation with other partner countries, including contributors and the neighbours to the south and to the east.

I would like to end my remarks with the possible way forward. I think we have to further operationalise the comprehensive approach, by better linking our conflict prevention, mediation, development and conflict resolution activities. CSDP has a vital role to play in addressing forms of organised crime, such as trafficking of drugs, of weapons and, of course, of people. These are directly linked to conflict.

For example, the security threats in the Sahel also relate to the influx of weapons and militias as a result of changes in Libya. On this, the combination of all of the European Union’s tools in a coherent strategy is absolutely essential. We have to pay constant attention to force generation and capabilities.

The Council undertook to make every effort to address this challenge and I will examine innovative ways to improve force generation in order to make proposals in the first half of 2012. Force generation, by the way, means getting the right people in the right place.

Work on military capabilities should continue towards a systematic pooling and sharing, not only as an answer to financial constraints, but also as means of enhanced operational effectiveness in the long term. We also have to enhance the effectiveness of missions and operations.

The EU should act through CSDP missions and operations to add value, on the basis of identified needs, with clear objectives and exit strategies to deliver and sustain results. As long as we can deliver on the existing missions, I am always ready to take forward work on possible new missions – in particular, in regions of such strategic importance to Europe’s security such as the Sahel and Libya.

The common security and defence policy can only be as effective and ambitious as we let it be. It relies on collective political will and ambition to act. It also means that the CFSP budget should be able to respond to the financial aspects of force generation. The European Parliament’s support in the last months has been essential on this, and I would like to take this opportunity to express to all of you my gratitude.

I would like to close by thanking you for your support on the work on CSDP, to reconfirm my continued commitment to CSDP as an integral and indispensable part of the European Union’s external action and, as I began, to once again thank Mr Lisek for his report.

 
  
 

  Krzysztof Lisek, rapporteur. – (PL) Mr President, Baroness Ashton, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for the pleasant and warm words on the report. I would simply like to say that this report is, of course, the result of joint efforts. It is the fruit not only of my work, but also of the work of many members of the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and of the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I cooperated very well. I wish to take this opportunity to thank them all from the floor of this House.

I welcome what Baroness Ashton has said, and I am glad that you, Baroness, the representatives of the Member States and the representatives of the Council all show a strong understanding of the problem, the needs, and of everything that relates to the common security and defence policy at the present time. This policy still represents a major challenge for us. I think that both you, Baroness, and the Council recognise that in the European Parliament, in the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, and in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, there is strong support for actions to promote joint work, joint activities by the Member States, activities aimed at increasing our efficiency in the field of security and defence.

All of you, I hope, are familiar with the statement by the US Secretary of Defence, Robert Gates, about our capabilities in the field of security and defence. This statement was initially met with much criticism, but that criticism was made only at the outset. Subsequently, it turned out that many European politicians, including many officials at the European institutions stated that alas, the US Secretary of Defence was largely right. We face a great challenge, regarding both reform of the common security and defence policy and, of course, good cooperation between the European Union and NATO. In particular, the European Union should focus on the search for synergies that allow its Member States to optimise their budgets.

The financial crisis, which is currently a major issue for Europe, is a global phenomenon and, of course, it also affects the defence sector. There is a tendency to reduce defence spending in the Member States, which is obviously a concern for us. It is true that maintaining defence spending in times of crisis, when faced with social needs, is not an easy task for those in authority and for politicians, but we believe – and I personally believe – that security and defence must not be ignored even in such a turbulent and difficult period for European finances.

In the report, I present several ways to optimise spending, suggesting how the means at our disposal, albeit slightly less than we had available before, could be spent in a better way, more appropriately, more effectively. Of course, what Baroness Ashton said is also true: the idea of ‘pooling and sharing’, connecting and sharing out functions has now become a necessity. This will make cost reductions possible. We must identify the most promising, strategic projects in this area, as soon as we can. They should definitely include strategic transport, logistical support, medical assistance, education, mid-air refuelling, maritime surveillance, protection and measures in cases of emergency arising from the use of chemical, biological and radiological weapons, satellite communications and intelligence. There are many fields where this idea of ‘pooling and sharing’ may be implemented effectively. The role of the European Defence Agency is inestimable in this context. It will determine how we can coordinate defence planning in Europe in the best possible way.

Another important issue I have dealt with is technological development. Here, too, we have identified many shortcomings. The report also addresses the question of defence equipment procurement, tenders, and many other issues. All these matters require thought and I am very glad that Baroness Ashton agrees that we should simply get down to work.

 
  
 

  Evžen Tošenovský, rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – (SK) Mr President, I am speaking here about this issue in my capacity as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. It is very likely that, due to the financial crisis and the associated budget reductions, there will be programme cuts that have a negative effect on the defence industry. The absence of a common policy in this area may further exacerbate the negative impacts on the defence industry. A common arms policy may make sense from an economic perspective, but it may also threaten the sovereignty of individual Member States.

For these reasons, a European defence policy should lead to greater multilateral cooperation, while also taking account of the national characteristics of the defence industry. More specifically, in order to mitigate the impact of the financial crisis on the defence industry, it is necessary to consider greater consolidation of demand through joint research projects or through bundling of demand for shared capabilities. Exporting helps some firms to mitigate the impacts of the financial crisis, including firms that are not competitive internationally. These firms should continue to diversify their portfolios, perhaps into the area of civil security.

 
  
 

  Elmar Brok, on behalf of the PPE Group. – (DE) Mr President, Baroness Ashton, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Lisek and the Subcommittee on Security and Defence for the good preliminary work that they have done on this report.

For us, foreign policy obviously always means taking preventive measures in order to make military intervention unnecessary. That is the starting position for our policy. However, military forces are necessary for peacekeeping and peacebuilding. Where military forces are needed, we must deploy them sensibly and make the best possible use of the instruments available to us.

The report rightly makes it clear that we are not using our resources responsibly. When budgets are tight, we must ensure that we exploit synergies and this can only be done at a European level. Therefore, it is right that the report calls for a White Paper which, on the one hand, will define the objectives and interests of the European Union and, on the other, will link them with the means and resources available. In areas such as procurement, research and development, for example, we can achieve much more jointly than if each country were to develop and buy its own cartridges. The question of the European Defence Agency in particular is of crucial importance if we are to make any progress in this area.

I also believe that we can make more use of the multinational organisations of which there is an increasing number within the European Union and that we should evaluate our operational readiness and the legal problems relating to it. I think that joint efforts in this area will also help to protect our soldiers. In the case of Afghanistan, it is clear that each country is going in with different reservations and that there is no sensible cooperation. In addition, there is no possibility of implementing the Berlin Plus agreement with collaboration between NATO and the civil crisis management bodies of the European Union. There is a great deal of work to be done in the interests of our citizens, of people who want to stand up for freedom, and of our soldiers.

Baroness Ashton, you have rightly said that in order to achieve this, we need collective political will. This will have to develop gradually in some capital cities as a result of the limited budget funding available.

 
  
 

  Maria Eleni Koppa, on behalf of the S&D Group. – (EL) Mr President, Baroness Ashton, the report we are debating today, on which I wish to congratulate Mr Lisek, concerns the future of the defence sector in this time of financial crisis and is extremely interesting. As far as we are concerned, there are two basic issues: firstly, we need to ensure that synergies and cooperation are strengthened at European level, in order to prevent resources from being wasted and, secondly, we need to safeguard jobs in the defence sector. The current situation calls for smart coordination, in order to lay the foundations for an internationally competitive industry which can create prospects for new jobs in the defence sector. Unfortunately, the restructuring of the defence industry is inevitable. What we need to ensure is that it is done with as few consequences as possible on employment. In the final analysis, European solidarity, specialisation, interoperability and complementarity are, in our view, the guidelines for a progressive policy in the defence sector and an answer to the crisis.

 
  
 

  Norica Nicolai, on behalf of the ALDE Group. – (RO) Mr President, I believe that today’s debate on the Lisek report is significant to the future of the common security and defence policy.

I wish to welcome this substantive report which not only examines the subject, but also attempts to offer solutions and which, apart from all this, provides opportunities for achieving a cohesive security and defence policy. To paraphrase Al Gore, we now have the chance to turn this crisis into an opportunity for the defence industry and for the future of our common security and defence policy. However, I cannot but stress that this drastic decline in Member States’ defence budgets may pose a risk to our common security, may maintain the still considerable disparities between the United States and the NATO member countries in the European Union, and may make the EU vulnerable in terms of its reaction capability.

I believe that the instruments that we already have, by this I mean the European Defence Agency, must be used in a purposeful manner. We must increase its reaction capability and integration ability for this pooling and sharing policy, which is the only solution enabling Europe to have a common capability, not to lose the capability it has, to ensure its interoperability in the common defence system, and to be effective in the missions which it has and which, unfortunately, will probably continue.

To achieve this, I believe that Europe is obliged to develop a common technological and industrial base for itself, use its research capability which some Member States have, and continue to favour solutions promoting honest conduct in public procurement, because one of the factors which have made these budgets vulnerable is the issues arising from corruption in the defence procurement system.

We already have a code of conduct, but we will have to use this code of conduct much more effectively. When we successfully make a procurement, we will do it on the grounds of being an opportunity promoting the interests of Europe’s citizens.

 
  
 

  Reinhard Bütikofer, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – (DE) Mr President, Baroness Ashton, ladies and gentlemen, firstly, I would like to thank Mr Lisek for his positive report, which represents a genuine attempt, as Mr Brok has said, to make the most of the opportunity offered by the fact that all the national budgets are subject to cuts and that therefore, the current level of wastage in the area of defence procurement simply cannot continue. Mr Lisek is taking up the opportunity of the concept of pooling and sharing. I am pleased that he is attempting, by means of a few small amendments, to increase the pressure on the Member States slightly, but in a very polite way.

If that were the main content of the report, my group would be voting in favour of it tomorrow. However, there are also two negative points. On the one hand, an attempt is being made in the light of the shortage of money in the Member States to cannibalise the EU budget for defence spending. This cannot be right. It is not right to finance defence research via the EU budget as part of the Horizon 2020 programme or the Seventh Framework Programme. It is not right to finance the Defence College via the EU, to open up the Structural Funds to the defence industry, or to fund a military Erasmus Programme out of our budget. This is a distraction from the actual task in hand, which is to ensure that we combine efficiency and cost cutting.

Thirdly, I find it particularly strange that the initiative has been led by Members from the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, who are normally very much in favour of competition. This report attempts to undermine completely our achievements in the Defence Package with regard to transparency and competition in the process of tendering for defence equipment by claiming that the intention is to protect jobs. I can only ask you not to give in to this. We are tabling amendments for individual votes on specific paragraphs. This should not be included in this report because it is structurally conservative, promotes inefficiency and wastes money.

 
  
 

  Geoffrey Van Orden, on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Mr Lisek has produced a detailed and well written report. Unfortunately, however, he draws the wrong conclusions.

It seems that the answer to every problem in this House is more Europe. It is all about European integration. Our concern here instead should be more military capability and greater solidarity in NATO. That means serious operational commitment and political will, two elements sadly lacking in so many European countries.

I am afraid that the very real threats and challenges that we face will not be resolved by trying to apply the same procedures to defence as we have seen applied to the euro. The European Union should stop meddling in defence. Its ambition is a dangerous, wasteful distraction. The Libyan crisis should have provided more than enough evidence that CSDP was irrelevant. No one wanted an EU military involvement – neither the United Nations, nor indeed NATO – and the Libyan experience revealed very starkly the potential dangers of the pooling and sharing concept, which seemed so attractive to EU policy makers.

Germany even withdrew its crews from NATO surveillance aircraft, the AWACS, operating over Libya. What sort of example is that? Of the 28 countries who agreed NATO operations over Libya, less than half actually participated and fewer than a third were willing to participate in strike missions. How could you expect a country such as the United Kingdom, or indeed France, to rely on someone else to provide a vital military capability on our behalf?

This report trots out the Eurocrats’ line, their desperate quest for an invented strategic autonomy of the European Union, when actually we should be ensuring that our armed forces have the capabilities and interoperability to deploy alongside our closest and strongest military ally, which is the United States.

  Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE), Blue-card question. – (DE) Mr President, given that you are campaigning so strongly against the concept of pooling and sharing, how do you bring that into line with the fact that NATO has exactly the same concept for rationalising capabilities, but simply under another name?

 
  
 

  Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR), Blue-card answer. – Mr President, Mr Bütikofer makes my own argument for me. This is indeed all happening in NATO so why is the European Union trying to do things? Why is the European Union trying to replicate NATO? Why is it setting up institutions which merely duplicate those which already exist at NATO? The great merit of NATO, however, is that it is an intergovernmental alliance, and sovereign nations can choose whether or not they participate in particular operations. That is the great difference.

And we do not have pooling and sharing; we have common command arrangements when there are NATO operations. There are very limited pooling and sharing capabilities, and I have mentioned one of them and that is the AWACS (Airborne Warning and Control System). We saw what happened to the AWACS in the Libyan crisis, so we have to be extremely careful about this.

What we need are solid, reliable allies. When the going gets tough, they have got to turn out, even when it is politically difficult. They have to come up with the fighting capability and they have to be prepared to stick it out. That is what we want to see.

 
  
 

  Sabine Lösing, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – (DE) Mr President, today’s discussion takes place against the background of the economic and financial crisis which has deprived many people of their livelihood, their rights and their democracy, and against the background of the thousands of people, in particular children, who are dying of hunger throughout the world.   Sampo Terho, on behalf of the EFD Group. – (FI) Mr President, many European countries have actually cut their defence expenditure because of the euro crisis, including my own country, Finland. Cuts in defence appropriations also make Europe’s already minimal role in global policy even less important.   Jean-Marie Le Pen (NI). – (FR) Mr President, at the risk of shocking the more federalist among you, I believe that defence policy is an eminently national policy. It responds to the specific strategic, diplomatic and security needs of each nation. Sharing capabilities is nothing more than a drastic loss of sovereignty, the single market of military equipment a joke, when certain Member States stock up on mainly US equipment, believing their defence is guaranteed by Washington, while Europe is incapable of imposing Community preference in this area as in so many others.

Regarding the EU Member States’ common security challenges, there is nothing that cannot be resolved through intergovernmental cooperation, without any intervention from Brussels. I am sorry, but entrusting these areas to Baroness Ashton would mean recognising that Moody’s and Standard & Poors are legitimate in judging our economic policies; it would mean accepting that ‘Merkozy’ can impose a German Europe on 27 peoples, which is absolutely delusional.

For 30 years and more since the disappearance of the Soviet threat, defence budgets have been the first to be sacrificed on the altar of budgetary restraint, to the point where most of our military tools have become deficient or dilapidated, all in the name of purely financial considerations, with each country waiting for its neighbour or supposed US big brother to make the efforts it is no longer prepared to make itself. However, you are making a mistake. Only by returning to independent and resolute national policies will we be able to individually equip ourselves with the necessary resources, not only to ensure our national interest and security, but also to cooperate in the use of those resources so as to overcome common challenges.

Creating more weaknesses and shortcomings has never been a wise idea.
